III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Criminal history check, subject to requirements; staff qualifications
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4112
Section (4) A person with ongoing duties shall have both of the following:
Description (a) Ability to perform duties of the position assigned.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation A staff at the facility has been providing youth with nicotine vape
pens.
Investigation Interviews:
Foster Care Worker was interviewed via phone on December
3, 2024. Foster Care Worker reported she completed a home visit
with Youth A’s sister at Relative’s home and Youth A’s sister
reported Youth A disclosed a staff named Mason is providing
Youth A nicotine vapes. She denied hearing these concerns
directly from Youth A and stated Sister disclosed these concerns
to her. Foster Care Worker reported Youth A has never disclosed
any staff providing nicotine vape pens to her.
Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on
December 3, 2024, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker.
Youth A reported she does use nicotine but has never used it
while at the facility. She denied ever getting substances from
peers or staff at the facility. Youth A did not know who Mason was
when asked and stated there is no one named Mason who works
at the facility. She reported she does get her nicotine when she is
on home passes and did not want to state who she gets the
nicotine from. Youth A reported she gets it from other minors in
her life but not from anyone at the facility.
Youth B was interviewed face to face at the facility on
December 3, 2024, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker.
Youth B denied ever being offered or provided a nicotine vape pen
2

by any staff or youth at the facility. He reported is more aware of
youth trying to sneak in vape pens after community visits, but staff
will complete a room search if there is a concern found. Youth B
denied knowing anyone at the facility named Mason.
Youth C was interviewed face to face at the facility on
December 4, 2024, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker.
Youth C reported he has been caught having vape pens. He
denied getting these vape pens from any staff at the facility. Youth
C reported that he has gotten vape pens from other youth at the
facility when they go on home visits and has gotten them from
youth, who live in the community, that work with him in the
employment program. He denied ever getting vape pens from any
adults. Youth C reported has never heard of any youth receiving
or being offered vapes from staff.
Youth D was interviewed face to face at the facility on
December 4, 2024, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker.
Youth D reported he had been caught with a vape pen at the
facility. He reported he got the vape pen during his home visit and
he snuck it into the facility. Youth D denied being offered or
receiving any vape pens from staff. He denied hearing that staff
has ever offered any youth vape pens at the facility.
Administrator was interviewed face to face at the facility on
December 3, 2024, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker.
Administrator reported there is no staff or youth at the facility that
is named Mason. She reported there have been no reported
concerns of youth receiving nicotine vape pens from staff.
Administrator reported Youth A has disclosed in therapy that she
receives nicotine vape pens when she is on home visits. She
reported Youth A does get drug screened for nicotine and has
tested positive every time she returns from a home visit.
Administrator reported this has been discussed with Foster Care
Worker and Relative.
Relative was interviewed via phone on December 4, 2024, in
collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Relative reported she had a
home visit with Foster Care Worker on November 25, 2024, with
Youth A’s sister. She reported during that time Youth A’s sister
disclosed a staff named Mason had brought the nicotine vapes to
Youth A. Relative reported she was concerned about this as well.
MDHHS Worker was interviewed via phone on December 9,
2024. MDHHS Worker reported Relative had called him earlier
today reporting she had Youth A stay with her over the weekend.
3

She reported Youth A reported the vapes were coming from the
employment program. Relative reported Youth A’s sister reported
a different staff name. MDHHS Worker reported he spoke with
Administrator who reported no staff at the employee program with
that newly disclosed staff name. Administrator reported there are
three staff at the facility that have a similar name that Youth A’s
sister disclosed but they do not have contact with Youth A as they
do not work within her programming.
Staff 3, Staff 4, and Staff 5 were separately interviewed face to
face at the facility on December 11, 2024, in collaboration
with MDHHS Worker. Staff 3, Staff 4, and Staff 5 all work at the
facility and have the same name that Youth A’s sister disclosed to
Relative on December 9, 2025. Staff 3, Staff 4, and Staff 5 do not
work on the same unit as Youth A and never have had
interactions with Youth A. The three staff each denied hearing any
concerns or seeing concerns of staff providing vapes to the youth
at the facility. Staff 3, Staff 4, and Staff 5 denied every bringing
any vapes to the facility for the youth. The staff all reported that
there has been rumors of youth getting vapes at the employment
program where staff do not supervise. It was reported youth’s
pockets will get checked prior to leaving and exiting the units to try
to stop the contraband from being brought in.
Supervisor was interviewed face to face at the facility on
December 3, 2024, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker.
Supervisor reported there is no one by the name Mason who
works at the facility and there is also no youth who go by that
name. He denied hearing or seeing any concerns about staff
providing youth vape pens.
Staff 1 and Staff 2 were separately interviewed face to face at
the facility on December 3, 2024, in collaboration with MDHHS
Worker. Staff 1 and Staff 2 denied knowing anyone named Mason
who works at the facility or any youth who go by that name. They
both denied hearing or seeing any concerns about staff providing
nicotine vape pens to any youth at the facility. Staff 1 reported
there has been an issue with youth sneaking in vape pens into the
facility and they have completed room checks when there are
concerns. He denied ever having to do a room check on Youth A’s
room.
Documents Reviewed:
- Facility Staff List September 1, 2024-Decemebr 4, 2024-
There is no staff member named Mason. Youth A was
admitted to the program on 09/20/2024.
4

- Facility Professional Ethics Policy dated June 27, 2024-
Staff are expected to upload the highest ethical standards
related to their work with clients. This policy notes that staff
should always remain professionalism and positive role
model for the youth they serve.
- Youth A’s File- Youth A was placed at the facility on
09/20/2024. Youth A has been completing visits at
Relative’s home since 10/18/2024. When Youth A first
arrived on 09/20/2024 her nicotine level per the drug
screen was 2189.8ng/mL. On 10/13/2024 Youth A’s results
were 37.7ng/mL. When she returned from a visit on
10/27/2024 her nicotine lives went up to 1767.5ng/mL. She
also had a visit on 11/14/2024 to 11/17/2024 at Relative’s
home. On 11/14/24 her drug screen came back showing
negative levels of nicotine and when she was drug tested
on 11/17/24 upon her return her level for nicotine was
1202.5ng/mL. Youth A had a visit on 11/22/2024 to
11/24/2024 at Relative’s home. On 11/22/24 her drug
screen came back showing negative levels of nicotine and
when she was drug tested on 11/24/24 upon her return her
level for nicotine was 1124.0ng/mL. On 11/07/2024, Youth
A had her room searched at the facility due to concerns of
vapes on the unit and there were no items found in her
possession or in her room.
Analysis The facility is found in compliance as per staff and youth
interviews there was no reports of staff providing Youth A nicotine
vapes. Youth A admitted to getting a vape while on a home visit.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code Health services; policies and procedures.
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4142
Section (1) An institution shall establish and follow written health service
Description policies and procedures addressing all of the following:
(g) Methods for dispensing medication when the resident will be
off site.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth was not provided with medication when they left for their
home visit on 11/22/24 and had a manic episode.
5

Investigation Interviews:
Foster Care Worker was interviewed via phone on December
3, 2024. Foster Care Worker reported Relative disclosed to her
the facility did not provide Youth A’s medication when Youth A did
an overnight visit on November 22, 2024.
Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on
December 3, 2024, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker.
Youth A reported Staff 2 drove her to her home visit on November
22, 2024. She reported Staff 2 held onto her medication and gave
it to Relative when they arrived. Youth A reported she received all
her medications that weekend and there were no concerns. She
reported there have never been any concerns about not receiving
her medications during a home visit.
Relative was interviewed via phone on December 4, 2024, in
collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Relative reported that Youth
A is on a PRN medication, and this was not provided on the
November 22, 2024, visit. She reported that she did not believe
that it was negligence on the facility as the facility provided all
other medications and this was just an as needed medication. She
reported that the facility does not provide it unless requested and
she did not request it. Relative reported that since Youth A did
have more anxiety on that visit that the medication came with her
on the most recent situation.
Staff 2 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
December 3, 2024, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Staff
2 reported when a youth goes on a home visit, the staff is to pack
medications up in individual packets for the specific day and time
the youth need to take them when on a visit. She reported staff
are to use their online medication system to note the specific
medication is packed into each single envelope and are to lable
each envelope with the youth’s name, the date and time the youth
should take the medication, and what medication is in each
envelope. Staff 2 reported if a youth has a PRN medication that
does not get packed as this is an as-needed medication that
nursing has to be called to provide the youth the medication. She
reported on November 22, 2024, she transported Youth A to her
home visit with Relative. Staff 2 reported when she transported
the medication, the medication was put in the side of the driver’s
side door so it would be out of reach of Youth A. When they got to
the meeting spot, she handed the medication directly to Relative
and there were no questions about the medication.
6

Staff 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
December 3, 2024, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Staff
1 reported he was the staff who packed Youth A’s medication for
her visit on November 22, 2024. He reported he verified on the
computer system the medications that needed to be packed and
utilized Youth A’s bubble packs of medication to pack her
medications. Staff 1 reported he had an individual packet for
Youth A’s morning and night medication for each day she would
be gone. On each packet, it noted Youth A’s name, the date and
time the medication needed to be taken, and what medication was
in the packet. Staff 1 reported he is aware Youth A has a PRN
medication but that was not packed for the visit as it was not
requested and did not have prior nursing approval. He reported
Staff 2 transported the medications and Youth A to her visit. Staff
1 reported if there is ever any issue with medication while a youth
is on a home visit, the caregiver is instructed to call the unit
immediately. He reported if a caregiver ever calls about a
medication missing it becomes the staff’s top priority to get the
medication to the youth at the visit. Staff 1 denied ever receiving a
call from Relative about a concern for Youth A’s medication.
Administrator was interviewed face to face at the facility on
December 3, 2024, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker.
Administrator reported Youth A has a PRN medication for her
anxiety. She reported the staff are directed not to pack the PRN
medication as the policy is staff must contact nursing any time
there is a request to use the PRN medication. Administrator
reported the youth, caregiver, clinician/administrator, or worker
could request for the PRN medication to go on visits, but it was
not requested during Youth A’s visit on November 22, 2024. She
reported during the home visit, Youth A’s grandmother started to
ask her about the trauma she experienced which caused Youth A
to become more anxious. Administrator reported since that visit,
Youth A now goes to visits with a dose of her PRN for
emergencies as it was not needed before that. She reported the
caregivers are also able to call the unit to bring medication if it was
forgotten, needed, or if there is any issue. Administrator reported
there was no contact from Relative during that visit.
Documentation Reviewed:
- Facility Procedure- Handling and Administration of
Medications dated July 5, 2024- This policy notes that
clinicians/administration is responsible for informing the
staff and nurse of a client’s planned home visit or other
visits. The staff are responsible for preparing labeled
envelops of medication which indicate the client’s name,
7

medication, dosage, date, and time to be taken during the
anticipated absence. The staff are to give medications to
the responsible family member and not to the client.
- Staff 1 Human Resource File- Staff 1 has no disciplinary
actions noted within his human resource file. Staff 1 is up to
date on all required trainings. He had his most recent
medication training on 09/05/2024.
- Staff 2 Human Resource File- Staff 2 has a written
warning dated 10/10/24 for failure to pass correct
medication to a client by passing the wrong medication
dosage. Staff 2 is up to date on all required trainings. She
had her most recent medication training on 10/14/24.
Analysis Facility is found in compliance as the facility provided Youth A’s
prescribed medications that needed to be taken. The PRN
medication was not provided as there was no request for the PRN
medication at the time of the visit.
Technical Assistance
Technical assistance was offered to create a procedure as it
pertains to the PRN medication and home visits.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code Intervention standards and prohibitions
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not limited to:
(iv) Verbal abuse including the use of derogatory or
discriminatory language including negative references to a youth's
background or appearance or mental state. Yelling, threats,
ridicule, or humiliation are strictly prohibited.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth is being called names by staff member.
Investigation Interviews:
Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on
December 3, 2024, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker.
Youth A reported she does not like Staff 2 as she always gives out
consequences. She reported when walking to the gym Youth A
told Staff 2 to shut up and she heard Staff 2 call her a “fucktard”
8

under her breath. Youth A reported no one else was around and
she did not tell anyone about this situation.
Staff 2 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
December 3, 2024, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Staff
2 reported she never has called any youth, including Youth A, any
names or used inappropriate language around them. She reported
Youth A does not always get along with her because Staff 2 will
hold Youth A accountable for her actions.
Staff 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
December 3, 2024, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Staff
1 reported he has never heard any complaints or heard Staff 2
called any youth any names or used inappropriate language
around them.
Supervisor was interviewed face to face at the facility on
December 3, 2024, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker.
Supervisor reported he has never had a complaint from any youth
about Staff 2 using inappropriate language or calling them names.
He reported he receives all the anonymous complaints and has
never seen anything against Staff 2. Supervisor reported he has
seen Staff 2 only have positive interactions with the youth and
hold them accountable for their behavior.
Youth B was interviewed face to face at the facility on
December 3, 2024, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker.
Youth B reported he has never been called a name or heard
inappropriate language from staff at the facility. He denied hearing
any complaints from other youth about this. Youth B reported he
has no concerns with Staff 2’s interaction with the youth.
Youth C was interviewed face to face at the facility on
December 4, 2024, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker.
Youth C reported he has had problems in the past working with
Staff 2 as they did not get along. He reported that he had
discussions with Supervisor about this and tries to stay clear of
her when she is working. Youth C reported he gets frustrated
because she will give more consequences than others.
Youth D was interviewed face to face at the facility on
December 4, 2024, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker.
Youth D reported he has not had any concerns with Staff 2. He
reported he has not heard her call any youth names and has
never used inappropriate language around him.
9

Documentation reviewed:
- Staff 2 Human Resource File- Staff 2 has 2 disciplines in
her file not related to this investigation. Staff 2 is up to date
on all required trainings. She had her most recent training
during a team meeting on 09/03/2024 about appropriate
client support and safety.
- Facility Suitable Treatment and Freedom of Movement
policy dated April 2018- This policy notes that employee’s
responses and involvement with a client should always
reflect what is appropriate. The policy provides examples
that staff should not use obscene language towards a
youth, horseplay, or excessively disclose personal
information.
Analysis The facility is found in compliance. Youth A reported Staff 2 used
an inappropriate word. Staff 2 denies this occurring. During
interviews with Staff 1, Supervisor, Youth B, Youth C, and Youth D
they deny hearing Staff 2 ever use inappropriate language.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
